courseTitle: Determining the Coefficient of Static Friction

pageData.titleName2: Determining the Coefficient of Static Friction

pageData.text: In this investigation, you will explore the concept of , a resistive force that occurs between surfaces in contact with each other. The investigation will examine by observing a wooden block in contact with a smooth surface from a level resting position and from a resting position on an incline. A measurement of the force applied to the wooden block to induce motion and the determination of the will provide the data needed to experimentally determine the coefficient of static friction, μs.

pageData.title: Needed but not supplied:
text: Digital camera or mobile device capable of taking photos

pageData.title: Time Requirements

Preparation – 15 minutes 
Activity 1: Determining the Coefficient of Static Friction Determining the Coefficient of Static Friction for Wooden Block Using Applied Force – 20 minutes 
                 Determining the  Coefficient of Static Friction for Sandpaper Using Applied Force – 20 minutes
 Extension Activity 1 - 20 minutes

text: Analyze free body diagrams to determine the forces on a wooden block on a flat surface.
Analyze free body diagrams to determine the forces on a wooden block on an inclined surface.
Investigate the relationship between the coefficient of static <button class='glossary-text'>friction</button> and surface area of contact.
Investigate the relationship between friction force and <button class='glossary-text'>normal force</button>.
Determine the coefficient of <button class='glossary-text'>static friction</button> between a wooden block and different smooth surfaces.

pageData.text: Water is often used as a lubricant to overcome <button class='glossary-text'>friction</button>. To reduce friction, water must be able to separate the two surfaces it is in between. When it separates the surfaces, water can act as a barrier and the friction is reduced. But water isn’t always able to act as a lubricant. Have you ever tried to put on a pair of socks when your feet are wet? Generally, socks and gloves are not waterproof and are able to absorb water. When this occurs, the water on your skin cannot act as a lubricant, making it difficult to put on gloves or socks.

Another example of this is a wetsuit, often used by surfers or scuba divers. Putting on a wet wetsuit is made much simpler by the use of lubricants, either homemade or storebought. Just mix a little hair conditioner or dish soap with water to create a slippery surface inside the suit to reduce friction with your skin as you pull it on1.1Freediving Freedom. (2023). How To Put On a Freediving Wetsuit (the easy way). Freediving Freedom.com.
https://freedivingfreedom.com/equipment-info/how-to-put-on-a-freediving-wetsuit-the-easy-way/

pageData.altText: A man wearing the bottom half of a wetsuit and putting on the top half of the suit.

pageData.text: Forces are either conservative or nonconservative. Work done by or against a <button class='glossary-text'>conservative force</button>, such as the gravitational force, is independent of path. This means that for conservative forces, work depends on the starting and ending points of motion and not on the path taken between them. Works done by or against <button class='glossary-text'>nonconservative forces</button> depend on the path of motion. <button class='glossary-text'>Friction</button>, a force that opposes relative motion between surfaces in contact, is an example of a nonconservative force.

The force of friction is around us all the time. Friction opposes relative motion between surfaces that are in contact with each other. Friction also allows us to move and stop. This is evident if you have ever tried to walk on ice or stop a car on a slippery road. While friction is a common force, its behavior is fundamentally complicated and is not able to be fully explained. However, we can understand the general characteristics of friction through experimental observations.

One basic characteristic of friction is that it is parallel to the contact between surfaces and always in a direction that opposes the relative motion or attempted motion between the surfaces. If two surfaces are in contact and moving relative to one another, then the friction between them is called <button class='glossary-text'>kinetic friction</button>. <button class='glossary-text'>Static friction</button> exists between stationary surfaces and is usually greater than the kinetic friction between the same surfaces. Static friction can prevent the motion between one object in contact with another object. Kinetic friction takes the form of sliding, rolling, or <button class='glossary-text'>fluid friction</button>.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: Several cars as seen from behind, driving on a snow-covered road as snow falls.

text: <button class='glossary-text'>Sliding friction</button> is the resistance to motion created between two objects when they slide against each other.
<button class='glossary-text'>Rolling friction</button> is the force that resists motion when an object rolls without slipping over a surface.
<button class='glossary-text'>Fluid friction</button> is the resistance to motion that exists between the layers of a fluid in motion.

pageData.text: For each type of , static or kinetic, the frictional force is proportional to the , N. Frictional forces involve the interaction of material surfaces in contact and are approximated experimentally by determining the for the different materials being used. The coefficient of friction, μ, is the ratio of the friction force, Ff, to the normal force, N, acting on the object. It is represented mathematically by Equation 1.

pageData.altText: Equation 1: mu equals F sub f over N

pageData.text: The coefficient of friction, μ, is dimensionless; the normal force and the friction force have units of Newtons, and the direction of the friction force is along a line tangent to the surfaces in contact. How much force is needed to overcome <button class='glossary-text'>static friction</button> depends on the roughness or smoothness of the materials in contact and is proportional to the normal force. However, the coefficient of friction is not dependent on the surface area in contact or on the speed of the relative motion between objects.

Coefficients of static and <button class='glossary-text'>kinetic friction</button> depend on the pair of surfaces in contact and are determined experimentally. Tables listing the coefficients of kinetic and static friction for different surfaces are available; however, values from such sources are to be used for reference only, since determining the confidents of friction between specific surfaces requires empirical data. For a given pair of surfaces, the coefficient of static friction will normally be higher than that of kinetic friction. Figure 2 shows that when force is applied to objects in contact, static friction prevents the object from moving until the limiting friction value is reached. This is a simple diagram of friction force versus applied force.

pageData.altText: Figure 2: diagram showing friction force versus applied force

pageData.text: The limiting <button class='glossary-text'>friction</button> is the maximum friction generated between the two static surfaces in contact. Once a force is applied that exceeds the limiting friction, motion between the two surfaces will occur. When one surface is in motion relative to the other surface, the magnitude of the applied force is reduced, as shown in <button class='resource-text'>Figure 2</button>.

Figure 3 shows the forces acting for an object at rest on a flat surface. The forces acting on the object are an applied force, F, the N, weight = mg (mass, m, times the acceleration of gravity, g), and friction force Ff = μsN. Applying Newton’s second law of motion to the forces in the vertical and horizontal directions for the stationary object (a = 0), results in the normal force, N, equal to the weight = mg as shown in Equation 2 and the applied force, F, equal to the friction force as shown in Equation 3.

pageData.altText: Figure 3: free body diagram illustrating static friction on a flat surface
Equation 2: epsilon F sub vertical equals N minus m times g equals 0 yields N equals m times g
Equation 3: epsilon F sub horizontal forces equals F minus F sub f equals 0 yields F equals F sub f

pageData.text: Substitute these results into Equation 1 [μ = Ff /N] to get the relationship for the coefficient of , μs, for an object at rest on a flat surface shown in Equation 4.

pageData.altText: Equation 4: mu sub s equals f over m times g

pageData.question: Which of the following is the force that acts in the opposite direction of motion when two surfaces come in contact?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The force that acts in the opposite direction of motion when two surfaces come in contact is friction.

pageData.question: A block of wood requires an applied force, F, to keep it moving with constant velocity across a surface. Which of the following describes the normal force, N, if the coefficient of friction is 𝜇?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text:
If an object is moving across the floor at a constant velocity, the net force must be 0. The applied force must be equal (but opposite) to the applied force. Therefore, the force of friction, Ff = F.

We can rearrange Equation 1 to solve for the normal force to get N = F / 𝜇.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Forces are either conservative or nonconservative. Work done by or against a conservative force, such as the gravitational force, is independent of path. This means that for conservative forces, work depends on the starting and ending points of motion and not on the path taken between them. Works done by or against nonconservative forces depend on the path of motion. Friction, a force that opposes relative motion between surfaces in contact, is an example of a nonconservative force.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Forces are either conservative or nonconservative. Work done by or against a conservative force, such as the gravitational force, is independent of path. This means that for conservative forces, work depends on the starting and ending points of motion and not on the path taken between them. Works done by or against nonconservative forces depend on the path of motion. Friction, a force that opposes relative motion between surfaces in contact, is an example of a nonconservative force.

pageData.text: For this investigation, force will be applied to a wooden block to start it moving by the tension in a string over a pulley attached to an amount of mass. This basic setup is shown in Figure 4. For the experiment we will assume a massless, frictionless pulley. The applied force, F, in is the weight of the hanging mass, mg. The , N, represented by mg in Equation 4, is the weight of the block on the horizontal surface, Mg. Substituting these relationships into Equation 4 [μs = F/mg] gives the simplified version shown in Equation 5.

pageData.altText: Figure 4: friction experiment showing masses and pulley configuration
Equation 5: mu sub s equals m times g over M times g equals m over M

pageData.text: Therefore, in the setup of the coefficient of , μs, can be determined from the ratio of the hanging mass, m, to the mass of block, M.

Figure 5 shows the forces acting for an object at rest (a = 0) on a surface inclined at an angle, θ. The forces acting on the object are the normal force, N, perpendicular to the incline, weight = mg (mass, m, times the acceleration of gravity, g) acting vertically, and force, Ff, acting parallel to the incline (opposing the block’s movement down the incline). With the object on an incline the weight vector has components perpendicular and parallel to the incline. Applying Newton’s second law of motion to the forces in the perpendicular and parallel directions for the stationary object (a = 0), a relationship for the coefficient of static friction, μs, can be determined, shown in Equation 6.

pageData.altText:
Figure 5: coefficient of friction for an object on an incline
epsilon F sub perpendicular equals N minus m times g times cosine theta equals 0 yields N equals m times g times cosine theta 
epsilon F sub perpendicular equals m times g times sine theta minus F sub f equals 0 yields m times g times sine theta equals F sub f
Equation 6: mu sub s equals m times g times sine theta over m times g times cosine theta equals sine theta over cosine theta equals tangent of theta

pageData.text: In the extension activity, you will use the relationship of Equation 6, μs = tanθ, to determine the coefficient of static for an object on an incline. The object will be at rest on a flat surface, you will then gradually raise the surface creating an incline. When the object just begins to move, you will measure the angle of the incline and calculate the coefficient of static friction using Equation 6.

pageData.altText: A map of the procedural workflow of activity 1 of this investigation. To prepare, you will set up the foam board with the pulley. Then, you will attach the block, string and hoods to the pulley system and measure the initial position of the block.  In activity 1, you will add masses to the paper clip until the block begins to move. Then, you will measure the total mass needed to start the block moving. You will repeat this for 4 trials. Next, you will add a beaker filled with washers on top of the block and repeat the procedure for 4 trials. Then, you will cut sandpaper to the size of the wooden block, attach the sandpaper and repeat the procedure of adding masses until the block moves and then measuring the mass for 4 trials. Finally, you will add a beaker with washers to the sandpaper block and repeat the procedure of adding masses until the block moves and then measuring the mass for 4 trials. You will then proceed to activity 2.

A map of the procedural workflow of the extension activity of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in the extension activity, you will detach the pulley system and place the block on the foam board. Then, you will slowly incline the board until the block starts to move. Next, you will measure the angle needed to start the block moving and calculate the coefficient of static friction. You will repeat this for 4 trials. Then, you will add the beaker with washers and repeat the process of inclining the board and measuring the angle for 4 trials. Next, you will remove the beaker with washers, add the sandpaper and repeat the process of inclining the board and measuring the angle for 4 trials. Finally, you will add the beaker with washers to the sandpaper block and repeat the process of inclining the board and measuring the angle for 4 trials.

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing this investigation. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after the investigation and clean up the work area with soap and water after finishing. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the SI unit for the coefficient of friction?
The normal force between two surfaces is 150 N and the coefficient of kinetic friction is 0.42.  Which of the following is the force required to keep an object moving at constant speed?
The normal force between two surfaces is 50 N, and the force required to keep the object from just starting to move is 90 N. What is the coefficient of static friction between the surfaces?

The maximum force, which can be applied to an object without the object starting to move is 67 N and the coefficient of static between the surfaces is 0.33.  What is the normal force between the two surfaces?
Which of the following statements is true about the coefficient of friction?

options.text: All of these statements are true.
The coefficient of static friction is given by F<sub class='bodysubscript'>applied</sub>  = F<sub class='bodysubscript'>friction</sub>.
The coefficient of friction depends on the types of surfaces in contact.
The coefficient of friction depends on the force acting perpendicular to the surfaces in contact.
The coefficient of static friction will normally be higher than that of kinetic friction.

assestmentData.question: For two surfaces in contact, how are the coefficient of kinetic friction and the coefficient of static friction related?

options.text: The coefficient of kinetic friction is less than the coefficient of static friction.
The coefficient of kinetic friction is the inverse of the coefficient of static friction.
The coefficient of kinetic friction is equal to the coefficient of static friction.
The coefficient of kinetic friction is two times the coefficient of static friction.
The coefficient of kinetic friction is greater than the coefficient of static friction.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following statements about friction is NOT true?

options.text: Frictional forces act in the direction of motion.
The coefficient of friction depends on the force acting perpendicular to the surfaces in contact.
The coefficient of friction depends on the area of the surfaces in contact.
None of these statements are true.
All of these statements are true.

assestmentData.question: A wooden block with a mass of 180 grams is placed on a book.  The block just starts to move when the end of the book is lifted to a 7.7-degree angle.  What is the coefficient of static friction between the book and the wood block?

Read through the procedure.
Watch the following video on how to set up video recordings for physics experiments:

Create a work space. You will need to work on a table or desk where you can attach a clamp on the edge. The area will need to be large enough to hold the 36-inch foamboard on the table lengthwise from the edge.
Obtain the required materials.
Note: All measurements need to be recorded in SI units and contain the correct number of significant figures.

typeBefore.title: Work station set up for Activity 1A (7 steps)

pageData.text: Place the foamboard with its narrow edge parallel with the edge of the table or desk. Attach the clamp with pulley (provided in your lab kit) over the foamboard and edge of the table or desk (Figure 6).

pageData.altText: Figure 6: Experiment setup

pageData.text: Use the electronic balance to determine the mass of the wooden block. Record this value in Data Table 1 in the Lab Notebook.

Place the wooden block with its largest surface area side in contact with foamboard. Select the flattest, smoothest side to place in contact with foamboard and mark the opposite of the block. This mark will ensure you use the same contact surfaces for all trials.

Cut a piece of string approximately 60 cm long (0.60 m) and tie a loop in each end so you can attach it the hook on the wooden block, extend over the pulley, and hang down from the pulley. The wooden block should be approximately 30 cm (0.30 m) from the pulley.
Mark the initial position of the wooden block on the foamboard with a pencil or pen. This mark will be the starting location of the wooden block for all trials.
Fashion a hook(s), from a paper clip(s), for the end of the string hanging over the table or desk that will allow you to hang washers on it. Multiple paper clip hooks may be needed (Figure 7).

pageData.altText: Figure 7: Experiment setup

pageData.text: Attach the string to the hook on the wooden block and over the pulley; it should make a straight line to the pulley and be parallel to your table or desk. Let the other end hang over the pulley. Take a picture of your setup.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: For all of the trials in Part A and Part B, the same types of materials will be in contact, the wooden block and the foamboard. Based on the relationship for determining the coefficient of static friction, your results for all trials should agree to within a reasonable experimental error. Pay careful attention to make accurate and precise measurements.

In Activity 1, you will determine the coefficient of <button class='glossary-text'>static friction</button> of a block of wood on a foam board by adding mass to an attached pulley system until the block moves. You will repeat the trials by adding mass to the block and with sandpaper to measure how changing the mass and texture of the block affects its <button class='glossary-text'>coefficient of friction</button>.

pages.title: Determining the Coefficient of Static Friction
pages.pageTitle: Determining the Coefficient of Static Friction

typeBefore.title:
A
 Determining the Coefficient of Static Friction for Wooden Block Using Applied Force (7 steps)

pageData.text: With the configuration from the preparation, add the paper clip hook to the hanging string. Begin adding washers to the paper clip hook until the block just starts to move. Add large washers, then small washers, and then paper clips. (A second paper clip hook may be needed to hold enough washers.) A possible method for this process would be to add large washers until the block moves quickly; remove one large washer and replace the setup to the initial position. Then, add smaller washer(s) until the block begins to move; paper clips may also be added for refining the amount of mass.
Determine the mass of the washers plus paper clip(s) and paper clip hook(s) needed to start moving the wooden block. Record this value in Data Table 1 for Trial 1.
Calculate the coefficient of , μs, using the relationship of : μs = m/M. Record this value in Data Table 1.
Return the materials to the initial conditions.
Repeat Steps 1–4 for three more trials for a total of four trials. Your hanging mass values should be consistent. Additional trials may be required to ensure accurate and precise data.

Add an additional mass to the wooden block by placing the plastic beaker on top of the wooden block and adding six large washers to the plastic beaker. Determine the total mass, M, of the wooden block, large washers, and plastic beaker. Record this mass value into Data Table 2.

Place the materials in the initial setup configuration. Repeat Steps 1–4 for a total of four trials for the second mass, M. Your hanging mass values should be consistent. Additional trials may be required to ensure accurate and precise data.

typeBefore.title:
B
 Determining the Coefficient of Static Friction for Sandpaper Using Applied Force (9 steps)

pageData.text: Cut a piece of sandpaper the size of the largest surface area side of the wooden block. Attach this piece of sandpaper to the wooden block using pieces of tape formed into loops and attached to the non-sandpaper side of the paper (Figure 8).

pageData.altText: Figure 8: Attaching the piece of sandpaper to the wooden block

pageData.text: Using the same configuration from Part A, place the wooden block on the foamboard with the sandpaper side in contact with the foamboard (Figure 9).

pageData.altText: Figure 9: Wooden block sitting on top of foamboard with the block’s sandpaper side in contact with the foamboard

pageData.text: 1. Add the paper clip hook to the hanging string and begin adding washers to the paper clip hook until the block just starts to move (Figure 10).

pageData.altText: Wooden block sitting on foam board with the string attached to the paper clip hook

pageData.text: 1. Add large washers, then small washers, and then paper clips. (A second paper clip hook may be needed to hold enough washers.) A possible method for this process would be to add large washers until the block moves quickly; remove one large washer and replace the setup to the initial position. Then, add smaller washer(s) until the block begins to move; paper clips may also be added for refining the amount of mass.
Determine the mass of the washers plus paper clip(s) and paper clip hook(s) needed to start moving the wooden block. Record this value in Data Table 3 for Trial 1.
Calculate the coefficient of static friction, μs, using the relationship of Equation 5: μs = m/M. Record this value in Data Table 3.
Return the materials to the initial setup configuration.
Repeat Steps 2–5 for three more trials for a total of four trials. Your hanging mass values should be consistent. Additional trials may be required to ensure accurate and precise data.

Add an additional mass to the wooden block by placing the plastic beaker on top of the wooden block and adding six large washers to the plastic beaker. Determine the total mass, M, of the wooden block, large washers, and plastic beaker. Enter this mass value into Data Table 4.

Place the materials in the initial setup configuration. Repeat Steps 2–5 for a total of four trials for the second mass, M. Your hanging mass values should be consistent. Additional trials may be required to ensure accurate and precise data.
Cleanup your work space.

pages.title: Overview
pages.pageTitle: Determining the Coefficient of Static Friction Using Angle of Incline Method

pageData.title: Overview
pageData.text: In the Extension Activity, you will test determine the coefficient of static friction for a block on a foam board by elevating the board at an incline until the block begins to move and measuring the resulting angle of the board. You will repeat the trials by adding mass to the block and with sandpaper to measure how changing the mass and texture of the block affects its coefficient of friction.

pageData.title: Materials
pageData.subTitle: Included in the materials kit:
pageData.text:
• Wooden block with hook
  • Sheet of sandpaper

pageData.subTitle: Needed from the equipment set:
pageData.text:
• Foamboard, 36 inch
  • Ruler or protractor
  • Large washers
  • Plastic beaker

typeBefore.text: Note: For all of the trials in the extension the same types of materials will be in contact, the wooden block and the foamboard used for the incline. Based on the relationship for determining the coefficient of , your results for all trials should agree to within a reasonable experimental error. Pay close attention to make accurate and precise measurements.

pageData.text: Place the largest surface area side of the wooden block on the foamboard in the same location as used in the investigation.

Slowly raise the end of the foamboard farthest away from the wooden block until the block just breaks away and starts to slide down the incline. Be very careful to move the foamboard slowly and smoothly so as to get a precise value of the angle with the horizontal at which the block just breaks away.

Determine the angle of the foamboard with the horizontal when the wooden block begins sliding. You can measure this using the protractor or you can measure the hypotenuse and opposite side to determine the angle using inverse sine. Record this angle in Data Table E1.
Using , calculate μs = tanθ and record this value in Data Table E1.
Repeat Steps 2–4 for three more trials (a total of four trials), placing the wooden block in the same position on the foamboard for each trial.
Calculate the average coefficient of static friction and record this value in Data Table E1.
Place the plastic beaker on the wooden block and add six large washers to the beaker. Place the wooden block in the same starting location as in Step 1.

Slowly raise one end of the foamboard until the block just breaks away and starts to slide down the incline. Be very careful to move the foamboard slowly and smoothly so as to get a precise value of the angle with the horizontal at which the block just breaks away.

Determine the angle of the foamboard with the horizontal at which the wooden block begins sliding. You can measure this using the protractor or you can measure the hypotenuse and opposite side to determine the angle using inverse sine. Record this angle in Data Table E2.
Using to calculate μs = tanθ and record this value in Data Table E2.
Repeat Steps 8–10 for three more trials (a total of four trials), placing the wooden block in the same position on the foamboard at the beginning of each trial.
Place the piece of sandpaper used in Part B of the experiment on the wooden block.

Place the wooden block (sandpaper side on the foamboard) at the same location as in Step 1. Slowly raise one end of the foamboard until the block just breaks away and starts to slide down the incline. Be very careful to move the book slowly and smoothly so as to get a precise value of the angle with the horizontal at which the block just breaks away.

Determine the angle of the foamboard with the horizontal at which the wooden block with sandpaper begins sliding. You can measure this using the protractor or you can measure the hypotenuse and opposite side to determine the angle using inverse sine. Record this angle in Data Table E3.
Using , calculate μs = tanθ and record this value in Data Table E3.
Repeat Steps 13–15 for three more trials (a total of four trials), placing the wooden block in the same position on the book at the beginning of each trial.
Place the plastic beaker on the wooden block (with sandpaper) and add six large washers to the beaker.

Place the wooden block (with sandpaper plus beaker and washers) in the same starting location as in Step 1. Slowly raise one end of the book until the block just breaks away and starts to slide down the incline. Be very careful to move the book slowly and smoothly so as to get a precise value of the angle with the horizontal at which the block just breaks away.

Determine the angle of the book with the horizontal at which the wooden block begins sliding. You can measure this using the protractor or you can measure the hypotenuse and opposite side to determine the angle using inverse sine. Record this angle in Data Table E4.
Using , calculate μs = tanθ and record this value in Data Table E4.
Clean up your work space.
Return the materials to equipment kit and clean the area.
You have reached the end of the investigation. Follow your instructors directions to submit this assignment.

text: Should the results of your Coefficient of Static Friction be the same for Data Table 1 and Data Table 2?  Explain why or why not.  Determine whether the results of the experiment are within a reasonable experimental error (<10%) by calculating the percent difference for each Data Table.
Draw and label a free body diagram that shows the forces acting on the wooden block at the point the limiting friction was reached. Upload it here.

text: It takes a force of 27.2 N to push a 12.5 kg box horizontally with a constant speed over concrete. What is the coefficient of kinetic friction between the box and the concrete? Show your work.
The following data was collected for a friction experiment in which an object was observed moving at constant speed over a surface.

pageData.text: 1. Graph the Applied Force versus the Normal Force and determine the coefficient of friction. Upload your graph here. If using graphing software, upload the graph image rather than the spreadsheet file.
Click on the browse button to upload the file

pageData.text: E1. Draw and label a free body diagram that shows the forces acting on the wood block at the point the limiting friction was reached.  Upload it here.
Click on the browse button to upload the file

E2. Compare the results from Data Tables 1 and 2 with the results from Data Tables E1 and E2.  Are they similar?  Explain why or why not.  Determine whether the results of the experiment are within a reasonable experimental error (<10%) by calculating the percent difference.

E3. Compare the results from Data Tables 3 and 4 with the results from Data Tables E3 and E4.  Are they similar?  Explain why or why not.  Determine whether the results of the experiment are within a reasonable experimental error (<10%) by calculating the percent difference.

Equation 3: epsilon F sub horizontal forces equals F minus F sub f equals 0 yields F equals F sub f

pageData.content: Equation 5. Coefficient of static friction for figure 4
pageData.altText: Equation 5: mu sub s equals m times g over M times g equals m over M

pageData.content: Figure 5. Free body diagram for a block on an inclined plane
pageData.altText:
Figure 5: coefficient of friction for an object on an incline
epsilon F sub perpendicular equals N minus m times g times cosine theta equals 0 yields N equals m times g times cosine theta 
epsilon F sub perpendicular equals m times g times sine theta minus F sub f equals 0 yields m times g times sine theta equals F sub f

pageData.content: Equation 6. Coefficient of static friction for a block on inclined plane
pageData.altText: Equation 6: mu sub s equals m times g times sine theta over m times g times cosine theta equals sine theta over cosine theta equals tangent of theta

A map of the procedural workflow of activity 1 of this investigation. To prepare, you will set up the foam board with the pulley. Then, you will attach the block, string and hoods to the pulley system and measure the initial position of the block.  In activity 1, you will add masses to the paper clip until the block begins to move. Then, you will measure the total mass needed to start the block moving. You will repeat this for 4 trials. Next, you will add a beaker filled with washers on top of the block and repeat the procedure for 4 trials. Then, you will cut sandpaper to the size of the wooden block, attach the sandpaper and repeat the procedure of adding masses until the block moves and then measuring the mass for 4 trials. Finally, you will add a beaker with washers to the sandpaper block and repeat the procedure of adding masses until the block moves and then measuring the mass for 4 trials. You will then proceed to activity 2.

A map of the procedural workflow of the extension activity of this investigation. After completing activity 1, in the extension activity, you will detach the pulley system and place the block on the foam board. Then, you will slowly incline the board until the block starts to move. Next, you will measure the angle needed to start the block moving and calculate the coefficient of static friction. You will repeat this for 4 trials. Then, you will add the beaker with washers and repeat the process of inclining the board and measuring the angle for 4 trials. Next, you will remove the beaker with washers, add the sandpaper and repeat the process of inclining the board and measuring the angle for 4 trials. Finally, you will add the beaker with washers to the sandpaper block and repeat the process of inclining the board and measuring the angle for 4 trials.

data.title: Coefficient of friction (μ)
data.content: Represented by the greek letter µ, it is the ratio of the friction force to the normal force acting on the object

data.title: Conservative force
data.content: Any force whose work is determined only by the final displacement of the object acted upon (example: gravitational force)

data.title: Fluid friction
data.content: The resistance to motion that exisits between the layers of fluid in motion

data.title: Friction
data.content: A force that opposes relative motion between surfaces in contact

data.title: Kinetic friction
data.content: A contact force between two objects moving relative to each other

data.title: Nonconservative force
data.content: Any force whose work is dependent on the path taken (example: frictional forces)

data.title: Normal force (N)
data.content: The force that surfaces exert to prevent solid objects from passing through each other; it is perpendicular to the surface than on object contacts

data.title: Rolling friction
data.content: The resistance to motion created when an object rolls without slipping over a surface

data.title: Sliding friction
data.content: The resistance to motion created between two objects when they slide against each other

data.title: Static friction
data.content: A frictional force that exists between two stationary objects
